1 Predicting New Advertiser Spending Predict how much an advertiser is capable of spending before they begin spending 1.1 A beginning: How much of this advertiser’s budget are we getting and how much of it could we be getting 1.2 A middle: Signals for scalability 1.3 An end: Predictive analytics as a sales motion

1 Predicting New Advertiser Spending Predict how much an advertiser is capable of spending before they begin spending Keywords search advertising, budgeting, revenue forecasts, time series, web logs, data science 1.1 A beginning: How much of this advertiser’s budget are we getting and how much of it could we be getting Microsoft has a goal to grow its Bing advertising product from a $7 billion dollar per year business to a $10 billion dollar per year business. There are two major strategies it can leverage to achieve this goal: increase its Bing user base and syndicate partnerships to increase aggregate network supply and or increase its advertisers’ current share of wallet - the amount of an advertiser’s budget allocated toward Bing versus other publishers. As the search engine experience between Google and Bing has become undifferentiated, growing user base is a long term challenge. More immediate impact can be realized by focusing on capturing a greater share of advertisers’ wallet. To best direct sales teams in this effort, Microsoft needs to understand how much of an advertiser’s budget they could be getting relative to what they’re currently getting. Drawing this distinction falls into the scope of Microsoft’s Search Data Science team. 1.2 A middle: Signals for scalability Growing advertiser budgets with Bing’s current market share is at its core a big data problem. Initially, we need to understand three key elements: percent of targeted supply advertiser is capturing (search share), cost to advertiser of capturing incremental supply, and the advertiser’s capabilities to scale budget. Knowledge of the network supply and demand gap help sales understand maximum potential. However, understanding advertiser scalability allows sales teams to focus efforts on those advertisers that are most able to increase budgets. In other words, insight into advertiser scalability provides sales teams actual (as opposed to maximum) advertiser potential. Determining actual potential requires a prediction of how much an advertiser could spend. In order to make this prediction, Microsoft needs to build an analytics solution for forecasting the future values of multiple time series.[@ZoteroStart] Several data points will be crucial to this solution: Internet Explorer/Edge Bing traffic log files for any given domain, web traffic stats from major search networks (which can be provided by 3rd parties) and a domain business vertical-classification algorithm. These data points will serve as core signals in the model. First, the vertical classification algorithm will group the new advertiser with other like-advertisers. Web log data from the vertical cohort provides directional data on the amount of search demand for any given vertical. And traffic data from other publishers, like Google, help identify major variances in expected vs actual traffic. 1.3 An end: Predictive analytics as a sales motion By developing a model for how much an advertiser can actually spend, Microsoft can establish a benchmark for each advertiser and alert sales teams to how a particular advertiser is trending against its benchmark (share of wallet opportunity). Sales teams, in turn, can focus on those advertisers with the biggest upside - high spenders and high trailers. Better alignment between sales teams and actual advertiser potential can help optimize Bing’s sales motion and drive revenue growth at a faster rate. While this model can help Microsoft toward its $10 billion target, the possible downside is that sales neglects advertisers without share-of-wallet opportunity, creating a crowding-out effect. To counter this, sales teams should be held accountable for both total accounts and revenue in their book of business.
2 Using Machine Vision to Predict Wave Quality {#Surf’s Up} 2.1 Dawn Patrol Blues 2.2 Computer Vision Goes Surfing 2.3 Training on Real Waves.

2 Using Machine Vision to Predict Wave Quality {#Surf’s Up} Keywords surf forecast, video analysis, computer vision, machine learning, wave quality, OpenCV, parallax 2.1 Dawn Patrol Blues For those who work 9-5, catching surf usually means waking up at dawn. To sleep or not to sleep becomes the routine question. To help answer that surfers can consult several websites that offer daily forecasts and wave condition rankings. Some even offer live video streams. Yet surfers are all too familiar with the scenario of a good forecast going bad or of judgements based on live video proving poor. Known as the dawn patrol blues - these scenarious leave the early risers at the beach with no surfable waves in sight. But advancements in computer vision and machine learning offer new hope to avoid these situations. Through the analysis of real-time surf cameras, we can improve the current forecast methodology and perhaps develop an eye for good surf that out performs our own. 2.2 Computer Vision Goes Surfing How waves are created and how they are different depend on wind, fetch, swell period, and the ocean floor (bathymetry) [@misc]. Each of these variables, themselves, can fluctuate quite a bit, making accurate predictions of wave quality for most surf spots challenging. Current datasets used to gather these variables include information from: the National Data Buoy Center, NOAA (nationa oceanic and atmosphere administration) for tide information and offshore storms, General Bathymetric Chart of the Oceans, and localized weather conditions from Weather Underground. All of these variables are currently modeled into a forecast of 5 categories of wave conditions across major surf forecast sites: poor, fair, poor to fair, fair to good, good. What is actually used to define these categories is based on two factors: 1. Scientific knowledge of how swell interacts with bathymetry and local weather conditions 2. User feedback. User feedback is highly subjective and the current science behind wave prediction leaves low confidence intervals. Wave speed, wave height, and predicted time-on-wave are metrics that are directly observable via real-time cameras, and all offer a more confident, objective assessment of surf quality. Setting up a pipeline between Surfline’s camera feeds and a computer vision framework provides the analytics platform needed to run prediction models on the above mentioned metrics. Those metrics can then be fed back into surfline’s website. OpenCV[@misc] could offer the framework needed for video analysis and machine learning will provide the prediction models for the said 3 metrics. Obtaining these metrics pose challenges including identifying starting and stopping points within the video to calculate wave speed, reference points to calculate wave height, and surfing surfers to calculate time-on-wave. To overcome these, a known point of reference needs to be established for each surf spot. This might require manual labor. However, some surf spots already offer known references such as life guard towers which have standard heights. Once an absolute reference point is known, parallax can be used to measure distances which, in turn, will be used to quantify rates 2.3 Training on Real Waves. Adding in wave speed, wave height, and predicted time-on-wave from the model could eventually be used to train the independent variables modeled into surf forecasting and help fine-tune those models. The result should be forecasts with higher confidence intervals and a less biased status of wave conditions. However, most important, surfers are provided real-time information that is more useful in making a decision on whether or not to surf at a particular spot. These insights could also be leveraged by organizations like the World Surf League who are responsible for determining ideal surf conditions for competitions. The additional insight around local conditions will, at the very least, help surfers avoid those dawn patrol blues.
